Deep Transfer Learning for Multi-source Entity Linkage via Domain Adaptation

Di Jin University of MichiganAnn ArborUSA dijin@umich.edu ,  Bunyamin Sisman AmazonSeattleUSA bunyamis@amazon.com ,  Hao Wei AmazonSeattleUSA wehao@amazon.com ,  Xin Luna Dong AmazonSeattleUSA lunadong@amazon.com  and  Danai Koutra University of MichiganAnn ArborUSA dkoutra@umich.edu
Abstract.

Multi-source entity linkage focuses on integrating knowledge from multiple sources by linking the records that represent the same real world entity. This is critical in high-impact applications such as data cleaning and user stitching. The state-of-the-art entity linkage pipelines mainly depend on supervised learning that requires abundant amounts of training data. However, collecting well-labeled training data becomes expensive when the data from many sources arrives incrementally over time. Moreover, the trained models can easily overfit to specific data sources, and thus fail to generalize to new sources due to significant differences in data and label distributions. To address these challenges, we present AdaMEL, a deep transfer learning framework that learns generic high-level knowledge to perform multi-source entity linkage. AdaMEL models the attribute importance that is used to match entities through an attribute-level self-attention mechanism, and leverages the massive unlabeled data from new data sources through domain adaptation to make it generic and data-source agnostic. In addition, AdaMEL is capable of incorporating an additional set of labeled data to more accurately integrate data sources with different attribute importance. Extensive experiments show that our framework achieves state-of-the-art results with 8.21%percent8.218.21\% improvement on average over methods based on supervised learning. Besides, it is more stable in handling different sets of data sources in less runtime.

1. Introduction

Entity linkage (EL), also known as entity resolution, record linkage, entity matching, is a fundamental task in data mining, database, and knowledge integration with numerous applications, including deduplication, data cleaning, user stitching, and more. The key idea is to identify records across different data sources (e.g., databases, websites, knowledge base, etc.) that represent the same real-world entity. For example, some music websites record the song ”Hey Jude” by Paul McCartney with the name abbreviation (i.e., “P.M.”) while others with the band name (i.e., “The Beatles”). As newly-generated data surge over time, accurately consolidating the same entities across semi-structured web sources becomes increasingly important, especially in areas such as knowledge base establishment (Dong and Naumann, 2009; Getoor and Machanavajjhala, 2012) and personalization (Jin et al., 2019).

Methods for solving the entity linkage problem across data sources include rule reasoning (Fan et al., 2009; Singh et al., 2017), computation of similarity between attributes or schemas (Bilenko and Mooney, 2003), and active learning (Qian et al., 2017). In particular, recent deep learning approaches that are based on heterogeneous schema matching or word matching (Mudgal et al., 2018; Nie et al., 2019; Li et al., 2020) have been widely studied. Their promising performance mainly comes from the sophisticated word-level operations such as RNN and Attention (Mudgal et al., 2018; Fu et al., 2020) to represent token sequences under attributes as the summarization, or the usage of pretrained language models (Kenton and Toutanova, 2019) to better learn the word semantics. However, all the above learning approaches implicitly assume that the “matching/non-matching” info for training records is available (e.g., the music records in source 1 and source 2 shown in the two blue tables of Fig. 1) and can be queried through the learning process, which does not always hold in practice. In real-world knowledge integration scenarios, new data come incrementally, and it can be either well-labeled (e.g., through manual confirmation) or unlabeled. While the existing frameworks can handle high-quality labeled data, they cannot deal with the massive volume of unlabeled and previously unseen data or missing values. As the example shown in Fig. 1, a model trained on the high-quality labeled data (blue tables) would fail to generalize to the new data sources (red tables) with missing and different attribute values (i.e., “Artist”), as well as new attributes or attributes that are rarely seen (i.e., “Gender”).

Motivated by real-world knowledge integration settings, we consider three key challenges in the multi-data source scenario: (C1) missing attribute values from unseen data sources; (C2) new attributes from unseen data sources; and (C3) different value distribution in unseen data sources. Based on these challenges, we seek to tackle the following MEL (multi-source entity linkage) problem: Given labeled data from a limited set of sources, what knowledge can be learned and how can it be transferred to automatically handle multiple unseen data sources with different value distribution, missing values and new attributes?

To solve this task, human experts typically rely on prior domain knowledge to learn the attribute importance in the seen data sources, and then transfer it to match the unseen records based on the similarity of attribute values. As challenges (C1-C3) lead to different attribute importance, human experts would update their knowledge learned from the seen data sources and adapt to the unseen data sources. For example in Figure 1, when trying to link entities in the red table, the importance of “Artist” learned in the seen data sources (blue table) is down-weighted due to the fact that name abbreviation is less informative. On the other hand, even though it is a rarely-seen attribute in the seen sources, “Gender” would be more important because the gender difference between artists naturally leads to non-matching of music records regardless of the fact that entity pairs could share the same “Title” (“Hello”) and very similar “Artist” values (“A. A.” and “A. W.”). This process, however, is tedious and does not scale to massive unlabeled data involved in real-world entity linkage problems, where large volumes of new data sources continuously arrive.

Following this intuition, we propose AdaMEL, a transfer learning framework that leverages both the labeled and massive unlabeled data to train the model for multi-source entity linkage while addressing the aforementioned challenges (C1-C3). We define the attribute importance in entity linkage as the high-level transferable knowledge and automatically learn it through a proposed attribute-level attention mechanism (what to transfer). In general, as transfer learning aims to transfers knowledge learned from the domain with abundant training data to a related target domain with limited data, the existing works either rely on increasing the labeling volume by introducing the external data (e.g., public knowledge bases) (Zhao and He, 2019) or reusing the seen training data (Thirumuruganathan et al., 2018). On the contrary, AdaMEL adopts domain adaptation (DA) to jointly update the attention scores for attributes in both the seen and unseen data as the basis for entity linkage (how to handle multiple sources), so that the knowledge is adaptive to the continuously incoming data sources. In addition, the insightful feature importance as transferrable knowledge is explicitly defined by AdaMEL to benefit both human interpretation and the performance of learning tasks, which is also different from methods that incorporates the knowledge into pretrained models like “black-boxes”, such as the contextual word/character embeddings. While the widely-adopted NLP-based attribute summarization in existing works (Li et al., 2020; Nie et al., 2019; Fu et al., 2020) could accurately capture the word-level semantics using some pretrained language models or domain knowledge for all attributes, they are too computationally expensive for the practical scenario. On the contrary, the feature-level attention is much faster to obtain and we claim that the impact of word-level similarity under some attributes is limited and even harmful for model performance if those attributes are not important.

AdaMEL follows the real-world scenario and assumes that new data sources come from the same or neighboring domains in batches (e.g., music from different websites). Transferring knowledge between irrelevant domains (e.g., celebrities and products) does not produce meaningful outputs and is out of the scope of this paper. We also propose a series of AdaMEL variants for different learning scenarios in practice. Our contributions are summarized as follows.

  • •

    We formulate the problem of MEL in real-world knowledge integration where the incoming data of unseen data sources are associated with missing values, unseen attributes and different value distributions.

  • •

    We propose a deep transfer-learning framework that learns the attribute-level importance as the high-level knowledge, and incorporates massive unlabeled data across multiple unseen sources through domain adaptation to make it agnostic and transferable.

  • •

    We apply AdaMEL to multi-source entity linkage over both industrial and public datasets, and show that it achieves at least 5.92%percent5.925.92\% improvement in terms of mean average precision compared to the state-of-the-art deep learning EL methods.

2. Related Work

Entity Linkage (EL). Entity linkage has been and continues being a fundamental problem in the field of database, data mining and knowledge integration (Getoor and Machanavajjhala, 2012; Köpcke and Rahm, 2010; Doan and Halevy, 2005). Early works are based on the similarity between entity attributes (Fan et al., 2009; Doan and Halevy, 2005) through resolving the data conflicts (Dong and Naumann, 2009), linking relevant attributes through semantic matching or rule reasoning (Singh et al., 2017). Techniques such as blocking or hashing are normally applied to merge the candidate entities  (Cohen and Richman, 2002). The major drawback of these methods is the dependence on prior knowledge as the useful attributes are normally selected through human efforts. Recently, EL models based on deep neural networks (Mudgal et al., 2018; Joty and Tang, 2018) have been widely studied due to their capability in automatically deriving latent features and promising results in fields such as CV and NLP (Bengio, 2012; Luong et al., 2015; Finn et al., 2017). For example, DeepER (Joty and Tang, 2018) proposes to leverage RNN to compose the pre-trained word embeddings of tokens within all attribute values, and use them as features to conduct EL as the binary classification task. DeepMatcher (Mudgal et al., 2018) also takes the embeddings of attribute words as the input and uses RNN to obtain the attribute similarity representation.CorDel (Wang et al., 2020) proposes to compare and contrast the pairwise input records before getting the embeddings so that small but critical differences between attributes can be modeled effectively. There are also recent works that formulate entity linkage across different data sources as heterogeneous entity matching (Li et al., 2020; Fu et al., 2020; Nie et al., 2019), for example, EntityMatcher (Fu et al., 2020) proposes a hierarchical matching network that jointly match entities in the token, attribute, and entity level. Ditto (Li et al., 2020) proposes to leverage the pretrained language model (Joty and Tang, 2018; Kenton and Toutanova, 2019; Li et al., 2020) such as BERT or DistilBERT, as well as domain knowledge and data augmentation to improve the matching quality. The attention mechanisms (Luong et al., 2015; Vaswani et al., 2017; Veličković et al., 2018) are generally adopted by these deep models, where the goal is to improve the linkage performance by highlighting valuable embeddings, e.g., word embeddings within the attributes. The basis of these above deep models for heterogeneous schema matching is to accurately summarize the attribute words through advanced NLP techniques such as word token-level RNN (with attention) or pretrained language models. On the contrary, our proposed method does not require sophisticated computation to summarize words in each attribute. AdaMEL focuses on the impact of important attributes in matching and explicitly models their importance using the soft attention mechanism as the transferable knowledge. Such attribute-level importance is agnostic to specific data sources and generalizes better than individual words in the transfer learning paradigm.

Transfer Learning. In the transfer learning scenario, models are trained on a source domain and applied to a related target domain to handle the same or a different task (Pan and Yang, 2009; Goodfellow et al., 2016). The specific transferable knowledge that bridges the source and target domain has significant impact to model performance (Ying et al., 2018). A popular approach is to adapt the pre-trained model for the new task through fine-tuning (Kenton and Toutanova, 2019), or by adding new functions to specific tasks such as object detection (He et al., 2017). In terms of EL, TLER (Thirumuruganathan et al., 2018) is a non-deep method that reuses and adopts seen data from the source domain to train models for the new domain. Auto-EM (Zhao and He, 2019) proposes to pre-train models for both attribute-type (i.e., schema) and attribute value matching based on word- and character-level similarity. However, Auto-EM assumes the typed entities are from a single data source and the attributes are seen during training, and thus cannot handle the multi-source scenario with unseen attributes. A specific type of transductive transfer learning that is most relevant to our work is known as Domain Adaptation, where the source and target domain share the same feature space with different distributions (Sun et al., 2015), and models are trained on the same task (Wilson and Cook, 2020). Many well-designed algorithms propose to map the original feature spaces to a shared latent feature space between domains (Duan et al., 2012; Chattopadhyay et al., 2012). DeepMatcher+ (Kasai et al., 2019) extends DeepMatcher with the combination of transfer learning and active learning to achieve comparable performance with fewer samples. However, this work aims at dataset adaptation rather than the attribute matching, and the focus is not improving the matching performance. Another line of works proposes to pre-train models on the source and target domain (if labeling available) and then combine them through specific weighting schemes (Schweikert et al., 2008). The process of applying the trained model to handle previously unseen data is also known as zero-shot learning (Palatucci et al., 2009). Unlike the above approaches, AdaMEL explicitly learns feature importance by adapting to the massive unlabeled data from unseen sources as the transferable knowledge for the multi-source EL task.

3. Preliminaries

In this section, we first formally define the problem, and then provide several key notions relevant to our proposed solution. Symbols and notations used in this paper are listed in Table 1.

3.1. Problem Definition

An entity record is collected from a specific data source such as a website or a database, and is identified by its attributes. For example, a song record r=𝑟absentr= (“Sweet Caroline”, “Neil Diamond”, “USA”) is specified by the attributes 𝒜={title, artist, country}𝒜title, artist, country\mathcal{A}=\{\texttt{title, artist, country}\}. We start with the formal definition of entity linkage.

Problem 1 (EL: Entity Linkage).

Given two entity records r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} associated with the same set of attributes 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} (schema), entity linkage aims to predict if r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} refers to the same real-world entity.

In this paper, we conduct analysis based on entity pairs (r,r′)𝑟superscript𝑟′(r,r^{\prime}) instead of individual entity records. We now define the MEL problem, which is related to heterogeneous entity matching111 In MEL, the entities come from different data sources, and thus there may be new or missing attributes. On the other hand, in heterogeneous entity matching, the schemas are heterogeneous (i.e., they have different attributes, which may not be aligned) and the entities do not necessarily come from different data sources. (Nie et al., 2019; Fu et al., 2020).

Problem 2 (MEL: Multi-source Entity Linkage).

Given the labeled entity pairs {(r,r′)}seensubscript𝑟superscript𝑟′seen\{(r,r^{\prime})\}_{\text{seen}} from a limited set of data sources 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} where each entity record r𝑟r is associated with attributes 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, and previously unseen pairs {(r,r′)}unseensubscript𝑟superscript𝑟′unseen\{(r,r^{\prime})\}_{\text{unseen}} from the new data sources 𝒮′superscript𝒮′\mathcal{S}^{\prime} with attributes 𝒜′superscript𝒜′\mathcal{A}^{\prime}, multi-source entity linkage aims to predict if each pair in {(r,r′)}unseensubscript𝑟superscript𝑟′unseen\{(r,r^{\prime})\}_{\text{unseen}} represents the same real-world entity, where (r,r′)unseen∈(𝒮×𝒮′)∪(𝒮′×𝒮′)subscript𝑟superscript𝑟′unseen𝒮superscript𝒮′superscript𝒮′superscript𝒮′(r,r^{\prime})_{\text{unseen}}\in(\mathcal{S}\bigtimes\mathcal{S}^{\prime})\cup(\mathcal{S}^{\prime}\bigtimes\mathcal{S}^{\prime}), |𝒮′|>|𝒮|superscript𝒮′𝒮|\mathcal{S}^{\prime}|>|\mathcal{S}|. Since 𝒮≠𝒮′𝒮superscript𝒮′\mathcal{S}\neq\mathcal{S}^{\prime}, certain attributes in 𝒜′superscript𝒜′\mathcal{A}^{\prime} could be missing (C1), new (C2), or associated with values from different distributions (C3), and thus 𝒜≠𝒜′𝒜superscript𝒜′\mathcal{A}\neq\mathcal{A}^{\prime}.

The key notion in Problem 2 that is different from Problem 1 is that the linkage task is conducted on entity pairs sampled from a wider range of data sources than the labeled data used to train the model (ten or hundred orders of magnitude more in reality). Back to the example shown in Figure 1, while the trained model could make perfect prediction based on “Artist” only, it would fail to handle new records because the attribute “Artist” has missing or abbreviated values that contain less info. Moreover, the new data sources contain a rarely seen or unseen attribute (“Gender”). This issue can be addressed by aligning the union of ontology 𝒜∪𝒜′𝒜superscript𝒜′\mathcal{A}\cup\mathcal{A}^{\prime} with blank “dummy” attributes. Based on our definition, a solution to MEL should be able to (G1) make use of the massive unlabeled data from the new sources, and (G2) further improve the linkage performance by leveraging a few labeled record pairs from the new sources, if available (i.e., an additional support set).

3.2. Terminology

Here we discuss the necessary terminology of our framework,.

Definition 3.1 (Source & target domain).

The source domain 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} refers to a set of labeled entity pairs {(r,r′)}𝑟superscript𝑟′\{(r,r^{\prime})\} sampled from limited data sources that the model is trained on. The target domain 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} refers to the set of unlabeled pairs where each pair has at least one entity sampled from the data sources unseen in 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S}.

For clarity, we use the superscript ∗ to indicate the data source(s) of a record/domain. Following Definition 3.1, the seen and unseen set of data sources in Problem 2 are formulated as 𝒮=𝒟S∗𝒮subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑆\mathcal{S}=\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{S} and 𝒮′=𝒟T∗superscript𝒮′subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇\mathcal{S}^{\prime}=\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T}. Besides, given a pair in the target domain, it could either contain one entity sampled from the seen data sources in 𝒟S∗subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑆\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{S} and the other one from the unseen, i.e., (r,r′)T∈𝒟S∗×𝒟T∗subscript𝑟superscript𝑟′𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇(r,r^{\prime})_{T}\in\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{S}\bigtimes\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T}, or it has both entities sampled from the completely unseen data sources, i.e., (r,r′)T∈𝒟T∗×𝒟T∗subscript𝑟superscript𝑟′𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇(r,r^{\prime})_{T}\in\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T}\bigtimes\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T}. In both cases, achieving G1 requires data in 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}. To achieve G2, we introduce the support set.

Definition 3.2 (Support set).

The support set 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} refers to a small set of labeled entity pairs sampled from the same set of data sources as the target domain 𝒟T∗subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T}. It has at least one data source that is not contained in 𝒟S∗subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑆\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{S}.

The support set corresponds to the real-world scenario that a few newly incoming entity pairs are well-labeled (e.g., on-the-fly human annotation). Thus, entity pairs in 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S}, 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}, as well as 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} are all required to achieve G2 for MEL.

4. Proposed framework

We propose AdaMEL to address Problem 2, a deep framework that learns attribute importance as the transferable knowledge 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} (Section 4.1), and adapt it to multiple data-sources via domain adaptation . AdaMEL first extracts the contrastive relational features of entity pairs to derive the embeddings (Section 4.2). Then, by using the proposed attention embedding function f𝑓f, AdaMEL projects features from 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} into the same attention space (Section 4.3), and jointly learns the feature importance for data sources in both 𝒟S∗superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑆∗\mathcal{D}_{S}^{\ast} and 𝒟T∗superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑇∗\mathcal{D}_{T}^{\ast}. This process is conducted in an unsupervised or supervised domain adaptation manner (Section4.4), depending on the real-world scenario. The overview is depicted in Figure 2.

4.1. Formulation

In transfer learning, the generic transferable knowledge 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} is key to adapt the model trained on the source domain to the target domain. We denote our domain adaptation solution to MEL as the following binary classification task.

(1) y=M​(𝒦,(r,r′))∈{0,1}𝑦𝑀𝒦𝑟superscript𝑟′01y=M(\mathcal{K},(r,r^{\prime}))\in\{0,1\}

where M𝑀M represents the deep model that generates the binary prediction y𝑦y for the entity pair (r,r′)∈𝒟T𝑟superscript𝑟′subscript𝒟𝑇(r,r^{\prime})\in\mathcal{D}_{T}, where 111 and 00 indicate the matching and non-matching, respectively. As mentioned in Section 3.1, the key difference between 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} lies in the difference in data sources, therefore 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} should be data-source agnostic to address (C1)-(C3). To ensure 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} shares the same feature space as 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} (the prerequisite for domain adaptation), AdaMEL first aligns the ontology so that data sources 𝒟S∗subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑆\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{S} and 𝒟T∗subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T} share the same attribute schema, but the attribute values (word tokens) can vary significantly. By doing so, entity records reveal the following properties that correspond to the aforementioned challenges: (C1) entity records in the source/target domain contain missing values, i.e., r​[A]=𝑟delimited-[]𝐴absentr[A]=“” (empty string) for r∈𝒟S∪𝒟T𝑟subscript𝒟𝑆subscript𝒟𝑇r\in\mathcal{D}_{S}\cup\mathcal{D}_{T}, (C2) certain attribute values are completely missing for records in 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S}, i.e., r​[Aj]=𝑟delimited-[]subscript𝐴𝑗absentr[A_{j}]=“” for r∈𝒟S𝑟subscript𝒟𝑆r\in\mathcal{D}_{S}, but not in 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}, and (C3) rich texts under some attributes in 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} but sparse in 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} or vice versa.

4.2. Feature Representation

Given entity pairs (r,r′)𝑟superscript𝑟′(r,r^{\prime}) with the aligned attributes 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, AdaMEL leverages the attention mechanism to learn the importance of each textual attribute A∈𝒜𝐴𝒜A\in\mathcal{A} as the generic knowledge for transfer learning. However, instead of computing the attribute importance directly, AdaMEL parses each attribute A𝐴A into 222 contrastive relational features, which are word tokens shared by r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime}, and word tokens that only appear in one record but not the other. This is because the similarity or uniqueness of attribute between r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} gives independent and complementary evidence for linkage (Wang et al., 2020). Taking the attribute A=𝐴absentA=“music version” as an example, a pair of music recordings sharing the same word (i.e., “original” or “remix”) is not as strong an identifier for matching as it would be for non-matching if one recording is “original” while the other is “remix”. In addition, looking into both the similarity and uniqueness in attribute A𝐴A between entities would enrich the feature space and facilitate training the deep model. We describe the 2 contrastive relational features of an attribute A𝐴A as follows.

(2) {s​i​m​(A)={w}​ for ​w∈{r​[A]∩r′​[A]}u​n​i​(A)={w}​ for ​w∈{r​[A]∪r′​[A]−r​[A]∩r′​[A]}cases𝑠𝑖𝑚𝐴absent𝑤 for 𝑤𝑟delimited-[]𝐴superscript𝑟′delimited-[]𝐴𝑢𝑛𝑖𝐴absent𝑤 for 𝑤𝑟delimited-[]𝐴superscript𝑟′delimited-[]𝐴𝑟delimited-[]𝐴superscript𝑟′delimited-[]𝐴\begin{cases}sim(A)&=\{w\}\text{ for }w\in\{r[A]\cap r^{\prime}[A]\}\\ uni(A)&=\{w\}\text{ for }w\in\{r[A]\cup r^{\prime}[A]-r[A]\cap r^{\prime}[A]\}\end{cases}

where w𝑤w is the word token in attribute r​[A]𝑟delimited-[]𝐴r[A]. For clarity, we uniformly denote shared/unique tokens s​i​m​(A)/u​n​i​(A)𝑠𝑖𝑚𝐴𝑢𝑛𝑖𝐴sim(A)/uni(A) as “features” that contribute independently to entity linkage. Clearly, there are F=2​|𝒜|𝐹2𝒜F=2|\mathcal{A}| features for a pair of entities. To summarize the feature representation, AdaMEL sums up the embeddings of the cropped word tokens (Joulin et al., 2017; Vaswani et al., 2017; Mudgal et al., 2018) without using more sophisticated operations. The embeddings can be obtained using any pretraining language model, such as BERT (Kenton and Toutanova, 2019) or Fasttext (Joulin et al., 2017). For clarity, we use i𝑖i as the index of entity pairs and j𝑗j as the index of features. Thus, the token embedding vector of an entity pair (r,r′)𝑟superscript𝑟′(r,r^{\prime}) is denoted as:

𝐡𝐡\displaystyle\mathbf{h} =[𝐡1,𝐡2,⋯,𝐡F]absentsubscript𝐡1subscript𝐡2⋯subscript𝐡𝐹\displaystyle=[\mathbf{h}_{1},\mathbf{h}_{2},\cdots,\mathbf{h}_{F}]
(3) =[emb​(s​i​m​(Aj)),emb​(u​n​i​(Aj))]​ for ​j=1,⋯,|𝒜|formulae-sequenceabsentemb𝑠𝑖𝑚subscript𝐴𝑗emb𝑢𝑛𝑖subscript𝐴𝑗 for 𝑗1⋯𝒜\displaystyle=[\text{emb}(sim(A_{j})),\text{emb}(uni(A_{j}))]\text{ for }j=1,\cdots,|\mathcal{A}|

By doing so, we denote the entity pairs (r,r′)𝑟superscript𝑟′(r,r^{\prime}) as F𝐹F textual embedding features (F=2​|𝒜|𝐹2𝒜F=2|\mathcal{A}|) for matching. The complete process is depicted in Figure 3. Besides, AdaMEL leverages per-feature non-linear affine transformation to project the word embeddings to get the latent feature 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}:

(4) 𝐱=[𝐱1,𝐱2,⋯,𝐱F]=[σ​(𝐕j​𝐡j+𝐛j)]​ for ​j=1,⋯,Fformulae-sequence𝐱subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2⋯subscript𝐱𝐹delimited-[]𝜎subscript𝐕𝑗subscript𝐡𝑗subscript𝐛𝑗 for 𝑗1⋯𝐹\displaystyle\mathbf{x}=[\mathbf{x}_{1},\mathbf{x}_{2},\cdots,\mathbf{x}_{F}]=[\sigma(\mathbf{V}_{j}\mathbf{h}_{j}+\mathbf{b}_{j})]\text{ for }j=1,\cdots,F

where 𝐕jH×Dsuperscriptsubscript𝐕𝑗𝐻𝐷\mathbf{V}_{j}^{H\times D} is the learnable weight matrix, 𝐛jHsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝐻\mathbf{b}_{j}^{H} is the learnable bias vector, and σ𝜎\sigma denotes the non-linear activation function (e.g., Relu). With this representation, Equation (1) can be rewritten as: y=M​(𝒦,𝐱)∈{0,1}𝑦𝑀𝒦𝐱01y=M(\mathcal{K},\mathbf{x})\in\{0,1\}. Next we discuss how AdaMEL learns feature importance 222In this paper, we compute the feature attention as the transferable knowledge, feature importance. as the transferable knowledge 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}.

4.3. Feature Attention Embedding

Given a pair of entities denoted through F𝐹F features, AdaMEL defines the energy score of feature j𝑗j as ej=a​(𝐖𝐱j)subscript𝑒𝑗𝑎subscript𝐖𝐱𝑗e_{j}=a(\mathbf{Wx}_{j}), where 𝐱jsubscript𝐱𝑗\mathbf{x}_{j} is the H𝐻H-dimensional representation of latent feature j𝑗j, 𝐖H′×Hsuperscript𝐖superscript𝐻′𝐻\mathbf{W}^{H^{\prime}\times H} is a shared linear transformation, and a𝑎a represents the attention mechanism ℝH′→ℝ→superscriptℝsuperscript𝐻′ℝ\mathbb{R}^{H^{\prime}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}, as a single-layer neural network (parameterized with 𝐚𝐚\mathbf{a}). AdaMEL allows each feature to attend to the label y𝑦y independently and computes coefficients using the softmax function such that the normalized scores are comparable across all features. Formula in Equation (5) computes the attention score of feature j𝑗j:

(5) g​(𝐱j)𝑔subscript𝐱𝑗\displaystyle g(\mathbf{x}_{j}) =softmaxj​(ej)=exp⁡(𝐚T​tanh⁡(𝐖𝐱j))∑k=1Fexp⁡(𝐚T​tanh⁡(𝐖𝐱k))absentsubscriptsoftmax𝑗subscript𝑒𝑗superscript𝐚𝑇subscript𝐖𝐱𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐹superscript𝐚𝑇subscript𝐖𝐱𝑘\displaystyle=\text{softmax}_{j}(e_{j})=\frac{\exp{(\mathbf{a}^{T}\tanh{(\mathbf{Wx}_{j})}})}{\sum_{k=1}^{F}\exp{(\mathbf{a}^{T}\tanh{(\mathbf{Wx}_{k})}})}

Note that Equation (5) only generates the scalar attention score of feature j𝑗j for an input vector 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. To compute the scores of all features, we introduce the attention embedding function f𝑓f that learns attention scores of all F𝐹F features as follows.

(6) f​(𝐱)=f​([𝐱1,𝐱2,⋯,𝐱F])=[g​(𝐱1),g​(𝐱2),⋯,g​(𝐱F)]𝑓𝐱𝑓subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2⋯subscript𝐱𝐹𝑔subscript𝐱1𝑔subscript𝐱2⋯𝑔subscript𝐱𝐹\displaystyle f(\mathbf{x})=f([\mathbf{x}_{1},\mathbf{x}_{2},\cdots,\mathbf{x}_{F}])=[g(\mathbf{x}_{1}),g(\mathbf{x}_{2}),\cdots,g(\mathbf{x}_{F})]

In Equation (6), all features share the same 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W} and 𝐚𝐚\mathbf{a} to compute the attention scores. We denote f​(𝐱)j=g​(𝐱j)𝑓subscript𝐱𝑗𝑔subscript𝐱𝑗f(\mathbf{x})_{j}=g(\mathbf{x}_{j}), and ∑j=1Ff​(𝐱)j=1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐹𝑓subscript𝐱𝑗1\sum_{j=1}^{F}f(\mathbf{x})_{j}=1. AdaMEL takes the generated feature importance vector f​(𝐱)𝑓𝐱f(\mathbf{x}) as the transferable knowledge 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} for the entity pair (r,r′)𝑟superscript𝑟′(r,r^{\prime}), i.e., 𝒦=f​(𝐱)𝒦𝑓𝐱\mathcal{K}=f(\mathbf{x}).

In the learning process, AdaMEL feeds the feature representation coupled with its attention score to a 2-layer feed-forward neural network ΘΘ\Theta to perform the binary classification task:

(7) y^=Θ​(σ​(f​(𝐱)⊙𝐱))=Θ​([σ​(g​(𝐱1)⋅𝐱1),⋯,σ​(g​(𝐱F)⋅𝐱F)])^𝑦Θ𝜎direct-product𝑓𝐱𝐱Θ𝜎⋅𝑔subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱1⋯𝜎⋅𝑔subscript𝐱𝐹subscript𝐱𝐹\hat{y}=\Theta(\sigma(f(\mathbf{x})\odot\mathbf{x}))=\Theta([\sigma(g(\mathbf{x}_{1})\cdot\mathbf{x}_{1}),\cdots,\sigma(g(\mathbf{x}_{F})\cdot\mathbf{x}_{F})])

where ⊙direct-product\odot denotes the element-wise multiplication, σ𝜎\sigma denotes the non-linear activation (e.g., Relu) and y^^𝑦\hat{y} denotes the inference score for matching. AdaMEL uses the same attention mechanism to handle all records in the training and leverages the cross-entropy loss to update the shared parameters 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W}, 𝐚𝐚\mathbf{a}, as well as the learnable 𝐕𝐕\mathbf{V}, 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} through back-propagation:

(8) Lb​a​s​e=−1N​∑i=1Nyi​log⁡y^i+(1−yi)​log⁡(1−y^i)subscript𝐿𝑏𝑎𝑠𝑒1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝑁𝑖1subscript𝑦𝑖subscript^𝑦𝑖1subscript𝑦𝑖1subscript^𝑦𝑖L_{base}=-\frac{1}{N}\sum^{N}_{i=1}y_{i}\log{\hat{y}_{i}}+(1-y_{i})\log(1-\hat{y}_{i})

where yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} denotes the label {0,1}01\{0,1\}. To ensure that all learnable parameters can be updated correctly, AdaMEL initializes the missing attribute values (incurred by challenge C1, C2) with a fixed normalized non-zero vector.

We name this solution AdaMEL-base as it learns f𝑓f through the labeled data in 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and illustrate the architecture in Figure 4. The attribute importance learned under the supervision of labeled data in 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} will be carried over to the unseen data sources and may not generalize well as there is always new data from seen or unseen sources with different distributions (C3) in MEL. Next we discuss how AdaMEL adopts 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} sampled from multiple data sources to alleviate this issue and make 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} data-source agnostic.

4.4. Domain Adaptation-based Variants

Based on AdaMEL-base, we propose three variants that leverage domain adaptation to handle different learning scenarios.

4.4.1. Unsupervised Domain Adaptation

Our first idea is to adjust the learned attribute importance according to new distribution of unlabeled data. In Equation (6), the attention embedding function f𝑓f contains the shared attention mechanism a𝑎a parameterized by weight vector 𝐚𝐚\mathbf{a} and the shared transformation matrix 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W}. It only takes the feature embeddings 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} as input to compute the attention scores. Since 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W} and 𝐚𝐚\mathbf{a} are shared across the input data, the attention score vector f​(𝐱)𝑓𝐱f(\mathbf{x}) can be seen as projecting the input feature embeddings 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} into a hyper-plane that is parameterized by 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W} and 𝐚𝐚\mathbf{a}. Without introducing extra information such as entity pair labeling, we can project data from 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} into the same space as 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S}, and it holds as long as the ontology of the unlabeled data aligns with the labeled data, i.e., identical attribute schema between 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}.

Therefore, AdaMEL uses the KL divergence to measure the attention score distribution difference between the source and target domain as the regularization term to train the model. The loss is defined in Equation (9). At a specific iteration in the training, AdaMEL uses the up-to-date f𝑓f to project data from both 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} into the same feature attention space. Then, AdaMEL updates 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W} and 𝐚𝐚\mathbf{a} so that not only the cross-entropy loss introduced in Equation (8) is minimized, but also the KL divergence between feature attention distributions for 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}. In this way, feature importance for entity records in 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} is jointly updated with records sampled from a wider range of data sources in 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}, and thus being agnostic to previously unseen data sources that have significantly different value distribution (C3).

(9) Lun=(1−λ)​Lbase+λ​Ltargetsubscript𝐿un1𝜆subscript𝐿base𝜆subscript𝐿targetL_{\text{un}}=(1-\lambda)L_{\text{base}}+\lambda L_{\text{target}}

where λ𝜆\lambda is the hyperparameter that balances between Lb​a​s​esubscript𝐿𝑏𝑎𝑠𝑒L_{base} and Ltargetsubscript𝐿targetL_{\text{target}}. λ𝜆\lambda also measures the amount of adaptation to the target domain 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}. Ltargetsubscript𝐿targetL_{\text{target}} is given as follows.

(10) Ltarget=KL​(f​(𝐱),f¯​(𝐱′))=∑i=1|𝒟S|∑j=1Ff¯​(𝐱′)j​log⁡(f¯​(𝐱′)jf​(𝐱i)j)subscript𝐿targetKL𝑓𝐱¯𝑓superscript𝐱′subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑆𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐹¯𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝐱′𝑗¯𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝐱′𝑗𝑓subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗L_{\text{target}}=\text{KL}(f(\mathbf{x}),\bar{f}(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}))=\sum^{|\mathcal{D}_{S}|}_{i=1}\sum_{j=1}^{F}\bar{f}(\mathbf{x}^{\prime})_{j}\log(\frac{\bar{f}(\mathbf{x}^{\prime})_{j}}{f(\mathbf{x}_{i})_{j}})

where f¯​(𝐱′)j=1|𝒟T|​∑𝐱i′∈𝒟Tf​(𝐱i′)j¯𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝐱′𝑗1subscript𝒟𝑇subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐱′𝑖subscript𝒟𝑇𝑓subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐱′𝑖𝑗\bar{f}(\mathbf{x}^{\prime})_{j}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}_{T}|}\sum_{\mathbf{x}^{\prime}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{T}}f(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}_{i})_{j}, which represents the attention score for feature j𝑗j averaged over the unlabeled data. 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} and 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime} denote the feature vector in the source and target domain, respectively, and f​(𝐱i)j𝑓subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗f(\mathbf{x}_{i})_{j} denotes the importance of the j𝑗j-th feature in the i𝑖i-th entity pair. In practice, AdaMEL adopts batch learning to improve the training efficiency, i.e., minimizing the loss per batch instead of iterating through all records in the data. The unlabeled data could also come in batches, which makes f¯​(𝐱′)¯𝑓superscript𝐱′\bar{f}(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}) be the attention vector averaged over the batched unlabeled data instead of all in the target domain. By default, the batches are sampled randomly.

We name this solution AdaMEL-zero as it is based on unsupervised domain adaption without using any labeled data in 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} and performs linkage in the zero-shot manner. This model also follows the design pattern in (Ganin and Lempitsky, 2015). Figure 5 depicts the architecture and the algorithm is given in Algorithm 1. Line 5-6 project the affine transformation of entity pairs from both 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}. Line 7 computes f¯​(𝐱′)¯𝑓superscript𝐱′\bar{f}(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}), the attention vector averaged over entity pairs in the target domain. Line 10-12 computes each attention vector in the sampled batch f​(𝐱i)𝑓subscript𝐱𝑖f(\mathbf{x}_{i}) and adapt it to f¯​(𝐱′)¯𝑓superscript𝐱′\bar{f}(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}) to compute the loss Ltargetsubscript𝐿targetL_{\text{target}}. AdaMEL minimizes both the inference loss Lbasesubscript𝐿baseL_{\text{base}} and Ltargetsubscript𝐿targetL_{\text{target}} to train the parameters in f𝑓f and form the transferable knowledge 𝒦=f​(𝐱i)𝒦𝑓subscript𝐱𝑖\mathcal{K}=f(\mathbf{x}_{i}) for 𝐱i∈𝒟Tsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝒟𝑇\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{T} (Line 14). Line 16- 17 denote the inference.

4.4.2. Semi-supervised Domain Adaptation

In practice, a small number of labels may be available for the entity pairs coming from the target domain (e.g., through on-the-fly human annotation). Entity pairs in this support set 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} are sampled from the wide range of data sources and provide clues about the data characteristics of the target domain. To leverage this set of labeled data (G2), AdaMEL updates the attention embedding function f𝑓f under the supervision of 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} so that the projected feature attention vectors of entity pairs in 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} could match to those in 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U}. For this purpose, AdaMEL computes the centroid of the positive entity pairs in 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} as follows:

(11) 𝐜𝒟S+=1|𝒟S|​∑(𝐱i+,yi+)∈𝒟Sf​(𝐱i)superscriptsubscript𝐜subscript𝒟𝑆1subscript𝒟𝑆subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝒟𝑆𝑓subscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{c}_{\mathcal{D}_{S}}^{+}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}_{S}|}\sum_{(\mathbf{x}^{+}_{i},y^{+}_{i})\in\mathcal{D}_{S}}f(\mathbf{x}_{i})

The centroid of the negative pairs can be computed in a similar way with negative samples. Intuitively, entity pairs from the data sources unseen in 𝒟S∗subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑆\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{S} are more important in adaptation than those from the seen sources, and should be highlighted. AdaMEL measures such difference through the Euclidean-distance between f​(𝐱)𝑓𝐱f(\mathbf{x}) and 𝐜𝒟Ssubscript𝐜subscript𝒟𝑆\mathbf{c}_{\mathcal{D}_{S}}, as the deviating attention vectors are more likely to correspond to unseen data sources in the projected space. In the loss function shown in Equation (12), we compare the distance d​(f​(𝐱),𝐜𝒟S)𝑑𝑓𝐱subscript𝐜subscript𝒟𝑆d(f(\mathbf{x}),\mathbf{c}_{\mathcal{D}_{S}}) with the “mean distance to cluster centroids” to give higher weights to entity pairs in 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} that are deviating from seen data sources.

(12) Lsupport=∑yi=1d​(f​(𝐱i+),𝐜𝒟S+)d¯𝒟S+​log⁡yi^+∑yi=0d​(f​(𝐱i−),𝐜𝒟S−)d¯𝒟S−​log⁡(1−yi^)subscript𝐿supportsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖1𝑑𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐜subscript𝒟𝑆subscriptsuperscript¯𝑑subscript𝒟𝑆^subscript𝑦𝑖subscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖0𝑑𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐜subscript𝒟𝑆subscriptsuperscript¯𝑑subscript𝒟𝑆1^subscript𝑦𝑖L_{\text{support}}=\sum_{y_{i}=1}\frac{d(f(\mathbf{x}^{+}_{i}),\mathbf{c}_{\mathcal{D}_{S}}^{+})}{\bar{d}^{+}_{\mathcal{D}_{S}}}\log\hat{y_{i}}+\sum_{y_{i}=0}\frac{d(f(\mathbf{x}^{-}_{i}),\mathbf{c}_{\mathcal{D}_{S}}^{-})}{\bar{d}^{-}_{\mathcal{D}_{S}}}\log(1-\hat{y_{i}})

where d𝑑d denotes the Euclidean distance, d¯+⁣/−superscript¯𝑑absent\bar{d}^{+/-} represents the mean distance for all positive/negative pairs in 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} to the corresponding centroid. Thus, by integrating Ls​u​p​p​o​r​tsubscript𝐿𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝𝑜𝑟𝑡L_{support} with Lb​a​s​esubscript𝐿𝑏𝑎𝑠𝑒L_{base}, the updated loss of AdaMEL in the supervised setting is denoted as follows:

(13) Lssl=Lbase+ϕ​Lsupportsubscript𝐿sslsubscript𝐿baseitalic-ϕsubscript𝐿supportL_{\text{ssl}}=L_{\text{base}}+\phi L_{\text{support}}

where ϕ∈(0,1]italic-ϕ01\phi\in(0,1] is a hyperparameter that controls the impact of the labeled support set. The training process updates not only parameters in the neural network ΘΘ\Theta for better classification performance, but also the attention embedding function f𝑓f so that the projected positive and negative feature attentions are matched closer. In this process, feature importance from the new data sources unseen in 𝒟S∗superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑆∗\mathcal{D}_{S}^{\ast} can be incorporated to update the centroids 𝐜+⁣/−superscript𝐜absent\mathbf{c}^{+/-} in the supervised manner. We name this solution AdaMEL-few as it uses a few labeled data in 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}, and depicts the process in Algorithm 2. Particularly, line 9- 10 denote the training process of f𝑓f to minimize the loss Lbasesubscript𝐿baseL_{\text{base}}, and line 12- 13 denote the process of further training under the supervision of labeled samples in 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U}.

4.4.3. Hybrid Model

We further propose a hybrid model that incorporates both the labeled support set as well as the unlabeled data in the target domain in the training process. It can be seen as the composition of AdaMEL-zero and AdaMEL-few. The loss function is as follows.

(14) Lhybrid=(1−λ)​Lbase+λ​Ltarget+ϕ​Lsupportsubscript𝐿hybrid1𝜆subscript𝐿base𝜆subscript𝐿targetitalic-ϕsubscript𝐿supportL_{\text{hybrid}}=(1-\lambda)L_{\text{base}}+\lambda L_{\text{target}}+\phi L_{\text{support}}

This variant uses the loss Ltargetsubscript𝐿targetL_{\text{target}} defined in Equation (10) and Lsupportsubscript𝐿supportL_{\text{support}} defined in Equation (12). We name this hybrid solution as AdaMEL-hyb. The algorithm is similar to Algo. 2, the main difference is to incorporate Lunsubscript𝐿unL_{\text{un}} i.e., Equation (9) into the training process (line 9- 10) to learn the parameters simultaneously.

4.5. Parameter Complexity

We measure the parameter complexity of AdaMEL in terms of the numbers of learnable parameters that comes from three parts: (i) per-feature non-linear affine operations that transform the word token embeddings to the latent feature vectors, (ii) the shared feature attention embedding function f𝑓f, which includes learning 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W} and 𝐚𝐚\mathbf{a}, and (iii) the multilayer perceptron (MLP) ΘΘ\Theta with 1 hidden layer for classification. For (i), there are totally F𝐹F features, each feature is associated with 𝐕H×Dsuperscript𝐕𝐻𝐷\mathbf{V}^{H\times D} and 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b}, thus leading to 𝒪​(F​D​H)𝒪𝐹𝐷𝐻\mathcal{O}(FDH) learnable parameters. For (ii), as 𝐖H′×Hsuperscript𝐖superscript𝐻′𝐻\mathbf{W}^{H^{\prime}\times H} and 𝐚H′superscript𝐚superscript𝐻′\mathbf{a}^{H^{\prime}} are shared across all features, there are totally 𝒪​(H​H′)𝒪𝐻superscript𝐻′\mathcal{O}(HH^{\prime}) parameters. The neural network ΘΘ\Theta in (iii) takes the concatenated F​H′𝐹superscript𝐻′FH^{\prime}-dim features as input with one Hhiddensubscript𝐻hiddenH_{\text{hidden}}-dim hidden layer. Therefore, AdaMEL has totally 𝒪​(F​D​H+H​H′+F​H′​Hhidden)𝒪𝐹𝐷𝐻𝐻superscript𝐻′𝐹superscript𝐻′subscript𝐻hidden\mathcal{O}(FDH+HH^{\prime}+FH^{\prime}H_{\text{hidden}}) parameters to learn. We discuss the setup values of H𝐻H, H′superscript𝐻′H^{\prime} and Hhiddensubscript𝐻hiddenH_{\text{hidden}} in the configuration of Section 5, and empirically estimate the parameter number in Section 5.6.

5. Experiments

In this section we describe the experiments to evaluate properties and the performance of AdaMEL. Specifically, we aim to answer the following research questions: Q1. Does AdaMEL effectively handle MEL with the data challenges (C1-C3) under the transfer learning paradigm? Q2. How well does AdaMEL adapt feature importance in the target domain and how does it affect the linkage results? Q3. Are generated feature attention values meaningful? Q4. How stable is AdaMEL in handling different data sources? Q5. How does the size of support set 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} impact the performance of AdaMEL? We conclude with the model justification (ablation study, limitation).

5.1. Experimental Setup

Data In accordance with (Q1-Q5), we use both the public benchmark dataset from the Data Integration to Knowledge Graphs (DI2KG) challenge (di2kg, 2020) and two real-world datasets in different scales from an online-sales company. Both datasets are in the tabular form and the entities are associated with descriptive textual features. The data statistics and source info is given in Table 2.

  • •

    Music-1M is a weakly labeled corpus crawled from 777 public music websites. We name them website 1-7 for confidentiality. There are 222 entity types: artists and albums. Entity pairs are labeled following the hyperlinks in pages, so there might be mixed-type errors such as matching an artist to her album.

  • •

    Music-3K is a manually labeled corpus containing the same data sources as Music-1M. It has three types: artist, album and tracks. The manual annotation is based on 999 attributes such as the artist name and album title. Errors such as mixed-type matching are carefully corrected.

  • •

    Monitor contains monitor data from 242424 sales websites such as ebay.com and shopmania.com. We filter out attributes with >60%absentpercent60>60\% empty records, and get totally 131313 attributes such as product description, manufacturer info, condition status, etc.

Comparing with the public benchmark datasets (Mudgal et al., 2018), the above datasets are collected from larger ranges of real-world data sources with heterogeneous schemas. The attribute values in the above datasets are generally longer with diverse characters, which makes it harder to summarize the attribute representation. For example, for Music-3K, artist type, the averaged attribute length is 25.7525.7525.75 word tokens, and for Monitor, the averaged attribute length is 11.7311.7311.73 word tokens. On the contrary, this number is 6.266.266.26 and 5.215.215.21 word tokens for the benchmark “dirty” and “heterogeneous” Walmart-Amazon dataset (Fu et al., 2020), respectively. In terms of the Music datasets, as the music works come from different countries, many entities are recorded with non-English characters & phrases for attributes such as the title, album and artist names. Unlike Music-1M that labels entity pairs through website hyperlinks, Music-3K further inspects whether the pair of music works indicate the same physical copy (i.e., “Album”), or the same digital copy in formats such as remix or cover (i.e., “Track”). The Monitor dataset is highly imbalanced with more than 99%percent9999\% entity pairs being unmatched. Additionally, less than 50% entity pairs in this dataset have non-missing values for most attributes. Non-missing pairs of 5 attributes only exist in the target domain. These data challenges do not exist in the benchmark datasets (Mudgal et al., 2018), and we detail the analysis in Section A.2 of the supplementary material. All the above issues make the datasets more challenging and closer to the real-world knowledge integration scenario.

Baselines. The following baselines are used in this work.

  • •

    TLER (Thirumuruganathan et al., 2018) is a non-deep transfer learning framework that defines a standard feature space and reuses the seen data to train models for the new domain.

  • •

    DeepMatcher (Mudgal et al., 2018) is a deep learning framework that consists of 3 modules: attribute embedding, attribute similarity representation, and classification. The public implementation uses Fasttext to embed attribute words and uses attentative RNN to summarize attributes. We report results using the best-performing variant, DeepMatcher-hybrid.

  • •

    EntityMatcher (Fu et al., 2020) is a hierarchical deep framework for heterogeneous schema matching. It jointly matches entities at the level of token, attribute, and entity. The token-level matching strategy allows EntityMatcher to perform cross-attribute alignment. Fasttext is used to embed word tokens.

  • •

    Ditto (Li et al., 2020) is an EL system that leverages fine-tuned, pre-trained Transformer-based language models (i.e., BERT, DistilBERT, or RoBERTa) with optimization including domain knowledge injection, text summarization, and data augmentation with difficult samples.

  • •

    CorDel (Wang et al., 2020) adopts an alternative deep architecture to the widely-used “twin architecture”. It compares and contrasts word tokens to filter out minor deviations between attribute values before embedding. CorDel also uses Fasttext, and it shows higher performance with reduced runtime compared to DeepMatcher. Out of the variants, CorDel-Attention is reported to perform the best on dirty EL datasets.

We consider these baselines since they are reported to achieve state-of-the-art EL performance and outperform methods such as Seq2SeqMatcher (Nie et al., 2019) and DeepMatcher+ (Kasai et al., 2019). Most of them are particularly proposed to handle heterogeneous entity linkage.

Configuration. In our experiments, we follow the original paper and fine-tune the baselines for optimal performance. The statistics of training, support and testing data is given in Table 3. Specifically, Musci-1M shares the same testing set as Musci-3K. Monitor adopts all positive and randomly selected 100010001000 negative pairs to form the testing set (see Section A.1 of the appendix for more details). For DeepMatcher, we use its hybrid variant (bi-directional RNN with attention) to summarize attributes with 2-layer highway neural network ((hidden dim=300absent300=300)). The training epoches is set to 404040 with batch size =16absent16=16. For EntityMatcher, we use the full matching model that uses bi-GRU (hidden size=150absent150=150) to embed attribute word sequences with cross-attribute token-level alignment. The training epoch is set to 202020 with batch size =16absent16=16. For CorDel, we use the attention-based variant that learns the word importance within the same attribute to validate the effectiveness of our attribute-level attention module. Moreover, CorDel-Attention was shown to perform best on long textual attribute values, which matches the property of our input data. All these 3 baselines use the pretrained FastText (Joulin et al., 2017) to derive the 300-dimensional embeddings for word tokens in each attribute. We set the cropping size =20absent20=20 and sum the embeddings of word tokens as the feature embeddings for CorDel. The training epoch is set to 202020 with learning rate =10−4absentsuperscript104=10^{-4} and batch size =16absent16=16. For Ditto, we tested its optimization strategies and adopted the “token span deletion” for data augmentation, “general” domain knowledge and retaining high TF-IDF tokens to summarize the input sequences. We also tested all pretrained language models, i.e., bert, distilbert, and albert, and ended up using bert. The training epoch is set to 404040 with batch size=64absent64=64 and learning rate=3×10−5absent3superscript105=3\times 10^{-5}.

To evaluate the effectiveness of our proposed framework, we configure AdaMEL with consistent setup as the baselines. Specifically, we use the 300300300-dim Fasttext to embed word tokens for fairness because 333 of the 444 baselines also use it, even though AdaMEL supports any word embedding techniques such as Bert embedding (Kenton and Toutanova, 2019). We set the cropping size=20absent20=20 as CorDel. The hyparameters of AdaMEL are given as follows: the dimension of the projected embeddings per feature is H=64𝐻64H=64, the dimension of the hidden layer in f𝑓f is H′=256superscript𝐻′256H^{\prime}=256, and the dimension of the hidden layer in ΘΘ\Theta is Hhidden=256subscript𝐻hidden256H_{\text{hidden}}=256. The activation σ𝜎\sigma is set to be Relu. We set λ=0.98𝜆0.98\lambda=0.98 and ϕ=1.0italic-ϕ1.0\phi=1.0 in Equation (9),  (13) and  (14) for AdaMEL variants unless otherwise addressed. To train the AdaMEL, we use Adam optimizer (Kingma and Ba, 2014) for 100100100 epoches with learning rate =10−4absentsuperscript104=10^{-4} and batch size =16absent16=16. We conduct all experiments 3 times and report the mean and std. We run these experiments on the Linux platform with 2.5GHz Intel Core i7, 256GB memory and 8 NVIDIA K80 GPUs.

Evaluation Metric. We evaluate the model performance using PRAUC as it measures the precision-recall relation globally and handles data imbalance. We use the python Sklearn library to compute PRAUC based on the open-source implementation of all baselines.

5.2. Transfer Learning for MEL

Our first experiment is to verify the effectiveness of AdaMEL variants on the task of MEL (Q1). We simulate two real-world scenarios: (S1) data in the target domain (𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}) shares common data sources with the source domain (𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S}) (i.e., (r,r′)T∈𝒟S∗×𝒟T∗subscript𝑟superscript𝑟′𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇(r,r^{\prime})_{T}\in\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{S}\bigtimes\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T}), and (S2) data sources in the target domain are disjointed from the source domain (i.e., (r,r′)T∈𝒟T∗×𝒟T∗subscript𝑟superscript𝑟′𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇(r,r^{\prime})_{T}\in\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T}\bigtimes\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T}).

Setup. For the Music data, we use three data sources (i.e., 𝒟S∗={website 1, website 2, website 3}subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑆website 1, website 2, website 3\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{S}=\{\text{\emph{website 1}, \emph{website 2}, \emph{website 3}}\}) to train our model and test on all 777 sources (overlapping scenario S1) or only the 444 remaining sources (disjoint scenario S2) as the target domain 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}. In either scenario, we collect 100100100 samples (505050 positive and 505050 negative) from the corresponding 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} as support set 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U}. For the public Monitor data, we use entity pairs from 5 sources (i.e., 𝒟S∗={\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{S}=\{ebay.com, catalog.com, best-deal-items.com, cleverboxes.com, ca.pcpartpicker.com}}\}) to train the models. We use data in all 24 sources as 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} for S1, and the rest 19 data sources for S2, respectively. 100100100 samples are collected as 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} in the same way as Music. We also randomly picked different sources to form 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} to eliminate the randomness, and found similar patterns in the results.

Results. We report the results in Figure 6 with complete numerical results in Table 9 and  8 of Section A.3 in the supplementary material. Our first observation is that all AdaMEL variants tend to outperform the baseline methods and our base model without adaptation, AdaMEL-base. The heterogeneous entity matching baselines do not perform well on these datasets under the supervision of labeled data only. This is likely because of the long and noisy word sequences in the data and the difference in attribute value distribution across data sources that is unseen during model training. AdaMEL highlights the impact of important features, and only represent the sequences by summing the token embeddings. This confirms our conjecture that learning the attribute-level attention as the transferable knowledge is more effective in handling the MEL task than refining the word-level sequence representation. Also, we observe that out of all variants, AdaMEL-hyb achieves the best performance in all cases with 0.64%∼5.50%similar-topercent0.64percent5.500.64\%\sim 5.50\% improvement in PRAUC than the second-best (AdaMEL-zero in most cases), which demonstrates its effectiveness in integrating both the labeled support set 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} and unlabeled info from the target domain 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}. AdaMEL-zero performs better than AdaMEL-few on the “Artist” and “Album” type, while AdaMEL-few performs better on the “Track” type. This is likely due to the fact that the track records are more diverse than the other types as the digital-format music tracks can be remixed or covered by other artists. Thus, the high-quality labeled samples from 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} is of higher value. On the contrary, since the records are more consistent for the “Artist” and “Album” type, incorporating more records in 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} leads to higher improvement in MEL performance. Note Figure 6(b) shows that AdaMEL-few performs slightly worse than AdaMEL-base because the labeled samples from 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} only overfits to the trained model on the source domain, that deviates the actual feature importance for the massive unlabeled samples in 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}. To summarize, the improvement of AdaMEL-zero, -few and -hyb over the baselines indicates the effectiveness of domain adaptation in incorporating data in 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}.

Overall, AdaMEL variants achieve better performance on the overlapping scenario (S1) than the disjoint scenario (S2). This is as expected as the disjoint scenario represents an extreme case where data sources in 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} are less likely or even entirely not used in training the model if the support set is unavailable. Besides, the performance of all approaches running on Music-1M is lower than Music-3K. The main reason is that the data is weakly labeled as it simply follows the hyperlinks from the websites, and does not distinguish the actual media of the music work (i.e., the physical or digital copy). As the models are tested on the same well-labeled set, training on Music-1M could be vulnerable to cases such as mixed-type matching. Nevertheless, we observe that AdaMEL still achieves promising results in both hard cases of transfer learning for MEL, i.e., unseen data sources in the target domain and training on weakly labeled data, which further demonstrates the advantage of AdaMEL. Table 8 gives the result on Monitor. Similarly, AdaMEL variants tend to outperform the baselines and AdaMEL-hyb performs the best with at least 0.51%percent0.510.51\% improvement in PRAUC over the second best, EntityMatcher. On average, AdaMEL-hyb outperforms the baseline by 9.39%percent9.399.39\% improvement in the overlapping scenario and 11.55%percent11.5511.55\% improvement in the disjoint scenario. These results also validates our findings above.

5.3. Effectiveness of Adaptation

Adaptation is the key component to our proposed method. To evaluate how well AdaMEL learns feature importance adapted to the target domain (Q2), we study the effectiveness of λ𝜆\lambda adopted in AdaMEL-zero and AdaMEL-hyb as it controls the weight of adapting to unlabeled data in training (larger λ𝜆\lambda leads to more adaptation).

Setup. We run both variants of AdaMEL on the Music-3K dataset and report the performance on MEL. As discussed in Section 4.4.1, records from both the source and target domains are projected into the same space using the shared attention embedding function, and AdaMEL attempts to adapt the model to match these feature importance distribution. Intuitively, with sufficient adaptation, feature importance vectors from both domains should align well, and further benefit the linkage task. To validate this conjecture, we visualize the learned feature attention vectors using AdaMEL-zero and AdaMEL-hyb with different values of λ𝜆\lambda by projecting them into 2-dimensional space using TSNE (Maaten and Hinton, 2008). We also study the linkage performance of AdaMEL-zero and AdaMEL-hyb with different λ𝜆\lambda values on the “artist” and “album” type of the Music-3K dataset.

Results. In Figure 7, we observe that for both variants, feature attention vectors from 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} align better when λ=0.98𝜆0.98\lambda=0.98 than λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0, which confirms the effectiveness of adaptation. In addition, we observe that comparing with AdaMEL-zero (Figure 7(b)), AdaMEL-hyb (Figure 7(d)) generates better adapted results as the projected records from 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} are almost indistinguishable, which is as expected as the labeled support set is leveraged.

To evaluate the impact of adaptation to the linkage results, in Figure 8 we show the performance of our variants with different λ𝜆\lambda values. We observe that as λ𝜆\lambda approaches (but not equals) to 111, the general performance in terms of PRAUC improves for both AdaMEL-zero (0.80140.80140.8014 - 0.90910.90910.9091) and AdaMEL-hyb (0.82420.82420.8242 - 0.92010.92010.9201), which again demonstrates the effectiveness of adaptation. It is worth noting that when λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1, both AdaMEL-zero and AdaMEL-hyb perform worse without giving meaningful results. This is because at this point, AdaMEL-zero is trained without supervision of the labeling in 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S}, and the only term in the loss function is the regularization. AdaMEL-hyb is better as labeling in 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} is still used, but the overall performance deteriorates due to the lack of labeling from 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S}. As a result, the parameters trained (i.e., 𝐚,𝐖𝐚𝐖\mathbf{a,W}) would tend to only “match” the feature distribution between 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} that are not tailored to classification.

5.4. Attention Analysis

Setup. To testify whether AdaMEL learns meaningful feature attention values (Q3), we showcase the learned feature importance through the attention scores produced by AdaMEL on two datasets: Music-3K and Monitor. We only report the artist type and omit the other two types for brevity. AdaMEL-hyb is configured with the best performance (λ=0.98,ϕ=1.0formulae-sequence𝜆0.98italic-ϕ1.0\lambda=0.98,\phi=1.0) in the previous experiments.

Result. For the Monitor dataset in Table 4, we observe the long “tail distribution” of feature importance, i.e., the most important feature is “Page_title_shared” with significantly high scores, while the other features are with roughly the same low scores. On the other hand, we observe the more uniform distribution for the artist type in Music-3K dataset, which makes sense as all top features are related to the artist names. The learned attention scores on both datasets imply that the task of MEL could be addressed with some of the most remarkable features (importance inequality).

We further run AdaMEL-hyb on these selected important features only and compare the performance with the result using the other features, as well as all the features. For Monitor, we use 3 attributes (i.e., “Page_title”, “Source” and “Manufacturer”). For the artist type of Music-3K, we use the 3 name-related attributes (i.e., “Main_performer”, “Name”, Name_Native_Language), and “Source”. Similarly, for the other two types, we use their corresponding top important attributes, and report the results in Table 5. We observe that by using the selected important features only, AdaMEL is capable of achieving comparable and even slightly better performance than using all features with 2.21%percent2.212.21\%, 0.87%percent0.870.87\% and 2.92%percent2.922.92\% improvement in PRAUC on Monitor, Music-3K (artist) and Music-3K (album), respectively. For Music-3K (track), using the top attributes only performs slightly worse than using all attributes, which is likely due to the diversity of track records. Nevertheless, these experimental results show that model training can further benefit from feature importance as using all the possible attributes could introduce irrelevant or noisy input to the model (e.g., using album-related features when inferring the artist type). Also, they shows the effectiveness of the feature attention module of AdaMEL in learning reasonable feature importance.

5.5. Data Sources Analysis

In this experiment we simulate the real-world knowledge integration, where new data sources often arrive one by one incrementally (such as in batches from neighboring data sources), and testify the stability of AdaMEL in handling the various data sources under this scenario (Q4) .

Setup. We use the public Monitor dataset and compare AdaMEL-hyb with the optimal configuration (λ=0.98,ϕ=1.0formulae-sequence𝜆0.98italic-ϕ1.0\lambda=0.98,\phi=1.0 as shown in Section 5.2 and Section 5.3) with the best-performing baseline approach, EntityMatcher, and the fastest baseline approach, CorDel-Attention. In this experiment, we use 150015001500 entity pairs from the same 5 data sources as mentioned in Section 5.2 to train the models (i.e., 𝒟S∗={\mathcal{D}_{S}^{\ast}=\{ebay.com, catalog.com, best-deal-items.com, cleverboxes.com, pcpartpicker.com}}\}). To test the performance on MEL, we first randomly select 200200200 entity pairs from each of 777 data sources (the same 5 data sources as 𝒟S∗superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑆∗\mathcal{D}_{S}^{\ast} and 2 unseen ones, i.e., 𝒟T∗=𝒟S∗∪{\mathcal{D}_{T}^{\ast}=\mathcal{D}_{S}^{\ast}\cup\{yikus.com, getprice.com}}\}) and form totally 140014001400 pairs to create the target domain. Then, we incrementally add up to 200200200 entity pairs from 2 new sources (Δ​𝒟T∗Δsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑇∗\Delta\mathcal{D}_{T}^{\ast}) to 𝒟T∗subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T}, such that 𝒟T∗=𝒟T∗∪Δ​𝒟T∗subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇Δsubscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T}=\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T}\cup\Delta\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T}. Each of the newly added pairs {(r,r′)}𝑟superscript𝑟′\{(r,r^{\prime})\} contains at least one record from Δ​𝒟TΔsubscript𝒟𝑇\Delta\mathcal{D}_{T} to ensure new data sources are introduced to the target domain. As AdaMEL-hyb requires a small set of labeled entity pairs from 𝒟T∗superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑇∗\mathcal{D}_{T}^{\ast}, we randomly select 100100100 labeled samples from all data sources (𝒟S∗∪𝒟T∗superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑆∗superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑇∗\mathcal{D}_{S}^{\ast}\cup\mathcal{D}_{T}^{\ast}). This small set simulates the on-the-fly manual labeling in the real-world, and we fix it throughout each run of the experiment to ensure the impact of 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} is consistent. We also record the average runtime over all runs as an empirical study of the model efficiency.

Results. We report the performance of AdaMEL-hyb and the two baselines on MEL in Figure 9, as well as their empirical runtime. As shown in the figure, AdaMEL-hyb is more stable than both EntityMatcher and CorDel-Attention with significantly higher performance in handling the incrementally incoming data sources. This is due to the fact that AdaMEL-hyb continuously updates parameters in the attention embedding function f𝑓f to adapt to new data sources in 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}. Comparing with CorDel-Attention, EntityMatcher performs better and could occasionally compete with AdaMEL-hyb under some scenarios (|𝒟T∗|=17,21subscriptsuperscript𝒟∗𝑇1721|\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{T}|=17,21), but it is not stable as the performance fluctuates. Moreover, based on the table in Figure 9, AdaMEL-hyb takes much less time to train than CorDel-Attention and EntityMatcher. The empirical runtime comparison corresponds to our analysis in Section 4.5 as AdaMEL-hyb does not require sophisticated operations on word-level embeddings and thus having relatively less parameters to train. In practice, the number of parameters to train for AdaMEL-hyb is ∼2 219 520similar-toabsent2219520\sim 2\,219\,520, which is much less than the number given by EntityMatcher: ∼123 119 104similar-toabsent123119104\sim 123\,119\,104. These findings demonstrate the capability of AdaMEL in consistently handing MEL with a variety of incoming data sources, while being more robust. In addition, they strengthen our claim that finding important features as the transferable knowledge in MEL could benefit the model performance with reduced computational complexity.

5.6. Effectiveness of Support Set

Setup. To better understand the effectiveness of the labeled support set (Q5), we perform the sensitivity analysis with incrementally increasing numbers of labeled samples in the support set 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U}. Following Section 5.2, we randomly select 200 additional samples from 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} of the public Monitor dataset and create the support set with totally 300 labeled samples. We run two AdaMEL variants that leverage the support set, AdaMEL-few (ϕ=1.0italic-ϕ1.0\phi=1.0) and AdaMEL-hyb (λ=0.98,ϕ=1.0formulae-sequence𝜆0.98italic-ϕ1.0\lambda=0.98,\phi=1.0) in this experiment with |𝒮U|subscript𝒮𝑈|\mathcal{S}_{U}| ranging from 111 to 300300300 with step size =20absent20=20 (specifically, we “zoom in” the smaller values and have |𝒮U|={1,5,10,20,40,60,⋯,300}subscript𝒮𝑈1510204060⋯300|\mathcal{S}_{U}|=\{1,5,10,20,40,60,\cdots,300\}). In each run, the samples in 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} are randomly selected.

Result. The experimental result is shown in Figure 10. Our first observation is that at the initial stage of the experiment, the performance of both AdaMEL-few and AdaMEL-hyb improves as the number of used labeled samples from 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} increases. Particularly, we observe ∼1%similar-toabsentpercent1\sim 1\% performance improvement from |𝒮U|=1subscript𝒮𝑈1|\mathcal{S}_{U}|=1 to |𝒮U|=140subscript𝒮𝑈140|\mathcal{S}_{U}|=140 for AdaMEL-few and 2%∼3%similar-topercent2percent32\%\sim 3\% improvement for AdaMEL-hyb. This overall performance improvement is as expected since an increasing amounts of labeled samples from 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} are used to supervise the learning process. In the late stage (|𝒮U|>140subscript𝒮𝑈140|\mathcal{S}_{U}|>140), we observe that the performance fluctuates in each run and the overall performance saturates. This indicates that the feature importance learned by AdaMEL has sufficiently adapted and does not significantly change as more labeled data are collected in 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U}. Moreover, comparing with AdaMEL-few, AdaMEL-hyb performs similarly when the size of support set is small (|𝒮U|≤60subscript𝒮𝑈60|\mathcal{S}_{U}|\leq 60), and it consistently outperforms when |𝒮U|>60subscript𝒮𝑈60|\mathcal{S}_{U}|>60. This is likely due to the bias of feature importance brought by particular labeled samples selected when |𝒮U|subscript𝒮𝑈|\mathcal{S}_{U}| is small. When 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U} contains more samples, the learned feature importance becomes stable and sufficiently adapted to 𝒮Usubscript𝒮𝑈\mathcal{S}_{U}, and the outperformance given by AdaMEL-hyb over AdaMEL-few comes from the unlabeled samples from 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T}. As a rule of thumb, Figure 10 indicates that a small support set with |𝒮U|=100∼200subscript𝒮𝑈100similar-to200|\mathcal{S}_{U}|=100\sim 200 labeled samples from 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} is beneficial to learn feature importance and to improve the MEL performance of AdaMEL. Too few samples would incur bias to the trained model, while too many samples would be expensive to obtain in practice, and does not necessarily help improve the model.

5.7. Model Justification

In this section we run experiments to justify the design choices of AdaMEL and its limitation.

5.7.1. Ablation Study

We perform the ablation study of AdaMEL that uses the shared and unique contrastive features, as well as using both of them as the default setting. Table 6 shows that including the shared and unique attribute values capture different perspectives of the data and thus enriches the feature space. Including both achieves the highest performance with 0.41%−6.72%percent0.41percent6.720.41\%-6.72\% improvement over using one feature.

5.7.2. Performance on Single Domain

Here we compare AdaMEL-zero and -hyb with DeepMatcher on the benchmark datasets to justify their performance on well-labeled data from the same seen domain without the 3 challenges (C1 - C3). From Table 7, we observe that AdaMEL-zero does not perform as well as DeepMatcher on these benchmark datasets of one single domain. This shows the limitation of AdaMEL in handling data with no missing values or schema difference. The reason is likely due to the simplicity of AdaMEL architecture, as it aims to learn the data-source-level feature importance instead of improving the token-level embeddings as DeepMatcher or its variants. In the real-world knowledge integration process where data distributions are highly heterogeneous, transferring these token-level contextualized embeddings brings extra computation and does not always generalize well, as shown in Section 5.2. Nevertheless, even though AdaMEL is designed to handle data challenges in practice (C1-C3), we observe that AdaMEL-hyb performs comparably as DeepMatcher with reduced model complexity, which shows its effectiveness of adaptation.

6. Conclusion

In this work, we tackle the problem of multi-source entity linkage (MEL) and described a deep learning solution based on domain adaptation, AdaMEL. AdaMEL highlights the impact of important attributes in MEL and automatically learns feature importance that adapts to the both seen and unseen data sources as the generic transferable knowledge. We also propose a series of AdaMEL variants to handle different real-world learning scenarios, depending on the availability of labeled entity pairs from the target domain. Comparing to heterogeneous schema matching baselines, AdaMEL is able to handle hard transfer learning cases such as unseen data sources in the target domain and training on weakly-labeled data, while achieving on average 8.21%percent8.218.21\% improvement than the baselines based on supervised learning in PRAUC score for the multi-source entity linkage task. In addition, our experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of AdaMEL in adaptation, provide the analysis on the learned feature attention, and study the impact of different data sources as well as the size of the support set. Future directions include combining our work with advanced NLP techniques for sequence representation in attribute summarization to further improve the model performance in MEL, and extending our framework to handle data sources in different languages.

Appendix A Supplementary Materials

A.1. Public Data Processing

In this section we detail the processing of the public dataset, Monitor that is used in the experiment. We follow the ’monitor_label.csv’ file (1 07310731\,073 positive pairs and 110 082110082110\,082 negative pairs) from the DI2KG to create the labeled entity pairs that fall into the 24 data sources we are interested in. The resultant dataset, Monitor has 734734734 positive and 66 0616606166\,061 negative pairs. The source domain 𝒟S∗superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑆∗\mathcal{D}_{S}^{\ast} contains 5 data sources (i.e., 𝒟S∗={\mathcal{D}^{\ast}_{S}=\{ebay.com, catalog.com, best-deal-items.com, cleverboxes.com, ca.pcpartpicker.com}}\}), which contains 302302302 positive pairs. Thus, the test data includes all the remaining positive 432432432 pairs and randomly-selected 1,00010001,000 negative pairs.

We provide the code and the splitted public Monitor data in the following in the repo https://github.com/DerekDiJin/AdaMEL-supplementary.

A.2. Analysis of Public Data

To illustrate the data challenges (C1-C3), we provide detailed analysis of the Monitor data. We first study the difference of the source and target domain in terms of the attributes, i.e., missing attribute values (C1) and new attributes (C2). As the attributes associated with entity pairs, we plot the percentage of pairs without missing values per attribute, i.e., (r​[A],r′​[A])𝑟delimited-[]𝐴superscript𝑟′delimited-[]𝐴(r[A],r^{\prime}[A]) where r[A]≠,r′[A]≠r[A]\neq,r^{\prime}[A]\neq for A∈𝒜𝐴𝒜A\in\mathcal{A} in both the source and target domain. This metric also indicates the difference of data source attributes because for unseen incoming attributes, at least one entities in a pair should have the missing value. The result is depicted in Figure 11. Ideally, the percentage bars included in this plot should all be close to 1, and this holds for both data in the source and target domain. In fact, we observe this pattern in the benchmark datasets (Mudgal et al., 2018) (such as Beer, DBLP-ACM, etc.), which indicates few missing values and no significantly different attributes. For the Monitor dataset, however, the pattern is different. We first observe that only 2 attributes (i.e., “page_title” and “source”) are close-to-1, while for all the remaining 11 attributes, less than 50% entity pairs have complete attribute values. Such data sparsity reflects the challenge (C1). In addition, we observe that the percentages of pairs without missing values are significantly different for the source and target domain. Particularly, we find that there are 5 out of 13 attributes only have non-missing entity pairs only in the target domain, which can be seen as new attributes (C2).

To illustrate the different attribute value distribution (C3), we showcase the attribute value distribution of one attribute, “prod_type” as the representative. We plot the frequency distribution of 10 most frequently appearing word tokens. As shown in Figure 12, the distributions of attribute “prod_type” are quite different between the source and target domain, which indicates the challenge we attempt to address.
